pageContext.description:
One of Cranach's customary compositions with the Virgin Mary holding the Christ Child on her lap. Jesus takes some grapes from the hands of young Saint John while three angels hold a finely wrinkled red cloth behind them, forming a sort of canopy. A landscape at the upper left of the painting recalls the artist's training in the Danube school.

This work is outstanding for its firm drawing, the predominance of line over color and the elegant play of curves, counter-curves and undulations in the characters' hair. The light dilutes some profiles and slight sfumato effects create a certain degree of melancholy in the midst of this joyous scene.

[http://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/the-virgin-with-the-christ-child-saint-john-and-angels/](accessed 10.09.2012)

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
see pdf

- probably thinned and cradled because of extensive wood worm damage in the panel

[del Carmen Garrido, Curatorial file, Museo Nacional del Prado, 1983]

- thinned and cradled on the reverse with a later greenish grey application 
- the panel may have been trimmed slightly either side (confirmation requires further investigation)
- draperies appear somewhat flat (damaged and overpainted)

[cda 2013]

tests.text:
Kr: 30 MA: 10
Time 1 min ½ 
Distance: 1m
 
Material- Kodak x-omat
2 Plates 43 x 35 cm
 
x-radiography reveals areas of loss in the area of the middle angels left knee (this area has been extensively overpainted)

[Curatorial file, Museo Nacional del Prado, 1982]

Pigment analysis
Cross-sections: 
Flesh paint: 
-          ground layer
-          size/priming layer
-          lead white with a small addition of vermilion and earth pigments
-          possible second layer painted wet-in-wet
  
 
XRF –KEVEX (pigment analysis)
Red curtain: Pb, Fe, Ca
Blue: Cu, Pb
Flesh paint: Pb, C, Fe, Ca

[Curatorial file, Museo Nacional del Prado, 1982]

- Wood
- four vertical planks
- butt joined

- white ground (probably chalk/glue mixture)
- traces of an incised line are visible along the edge at the top of the left side
- some traces visible along the contour of St John's robe; arm of St John; foot of Christ; fine line over the right eyebrow of the Virgin and along the contour of her nose

-          sequence: flesh paint held in reserve blue paint of robe applied; final adjustments made to contours; typical painting sequence
-          red robe modelled in red with shadows applied in dark red glaze or black highlights in pure red wings of the angels simple blocked in area of colour, single feathers defined with very fine yellow lines; similar execution of St John's fur robe over a thin brown glaze
      -          applied with brushes of varying widths from broad to fine pointed brush
-          draperies appear somewhat flat (damaged and overpainted)
-          thin applications of paint
-          drying cracks visible in the brown glazes
-     black line along the top and bottom

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia on the left on the wall: winged serpent with elevated wings facing right and dated '1536'; in yellow paint

[cda 2013]
